Award.AwardTitle: Ultra High Sensitivity Wavefront Sensor for Extreme-AO and Visible-AO
Award.AbstractNarration:
Telescopes on the ground must observe objects in deep space through the interference of the earth's atmosphere. As light passes through the atmosphere it gets spread out by turbulence due to wind shear and changes in temperature and pressure within the atmospheric layers. These effects reduce the resolving power of earth-based telescopes, spreading a stellar point-source image into a resolvable "seeing" disk. This difficulty can be overcome to a large extent by monitoring a bright star near the object of interest and looking for the rapidly varying distortions and displacements of the reference star's image that are introduced as its light passes through the atmosphere. These "guide star" signals are fed into an Adaptive Optics (AO) system that uses a "wavefront sensor" and a "deformable mirror" to restore the image to (nearly) what would be seen from above the atmosphere.

These techniques have been with us for some time and are now becoming mature and routine, especially on larger telescopes where the diffraction limit is much smaller than the typical seeing disk. Dr. Olivier Guyon of the University of Arizona is developing a more complex and sophisticated approach to wavefront sensing that promises to deliver higher sensitivity plus a greatly improved ability to separate nearby objects, especially when one of them is much brighter than the other. This is very important for finding faint planets next to their stars. Currently most wavefront sensing is done using a linear approximation. Dr. Guyon will deliver a non-linear curvature wavefront sensing capability that he expects will enhance the contrast by a factor of 50 to 100 over current methods. Dr. Guyon's work is funded by NSF's Division of Astronomical Sciences through its Advanced Technologies and Instrumentation program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We have developed wavefront sensing techniques (hardware and algorithms) aimed at reaching significantly improved sensing sensitivity on large telescopes. Our approaches reach the sensitivity limit imposed by the telescope's diffraction limit, instead of the seeing limit currently achieved on most telescope. The equivalent flux gain ranges from 1,000 to 100,000 for the future generation of 30m-class telescopes, allowing ultra-precise fast wavefront control of atmospheric wavefronts. This approach's most significant impact is that it will allow direct imaging and spectroscopic characterization of habitable planets around nearby M-type stars using the upcoming generation of extremely large telescopes (TMT, GMT, E-ELT). This will be achieved by combining our newly developed diffraction limited wavefront sensing with small inner working coronagraphy and focal plane control.

Our team worked on two wavefront sensing techniques/architectures: the non-linear curvature wavefront sensor (nlCWFS) and the non-modulated pyramid wavefront sensor (nmPWFS): both sensors operate at the diffraction limit of the telescope, offering significant sensitivity gain over conventional seeing-limited sensors currently in use on most telescopes. For nlCWFS, we have built hardware prototypes in the lab and tested them on the 6.5m MMT telescope. For the nmPWFS, we used existing hardware on the Subaru Telescope SCExAO system, and demonstrated closed-loop operation in near-IR, in partnership with the NSF-funded SAPHIRA detector team at the University of Hawaii.

We have also developed software tools to operate these sensors and quantify their scientific return in the most challenging application: high contrast imaging of exoplanets.

Our team has demonstrated on-sky hardware implementation and operation of the nlCWFS using wavelength-splitting on the 6.5m MMT telescope. We have also demonstrated closed-loop operation of the nmPWFS using the Subaru Coronagraphic Extreme-AO (SCExAO) hardware. This has been done in the lab at 3.5 kHz frame rate in visible light and at 110 Hz in near-IR (speed limited by camera). The near-IR demonstration was performed in collaboration with the NSF-funded SAPHIRA detector team at the University of Hawaii.

The computing engine developed in part by our NSF award has demonstrated operation at 3.5kHz frame rate with 120x120 wavefront sensing elements and 2000 actuators using an array of 5 GPUs. The engine supports real-time operation of an AO system and was developed to be easily linked with any DM or WFS camera hardware using shared memory input/output arrays. Performance can be scaled up by using additional GPUs. The software was used for the first near-IR demonstration of a nmPWFS, which ran at 110 Hz.

We have also developed a physical model of atmospheric turbulence which includes chromatic diffraction propagation and chromatic atmospheric refraction. The model accurately captures the chromatic dependence in optical pathlength and intensity (scintillation), which is key to quantify near-IR speckle residuals left after correction using high performance visible wavefront sensors. The physical atmospheric model developed as part of this award is now the basis for quantitative performance estimation and design of an ExAO system for ELTs, aimed at direct imaging and spectroscopic characterization of habitable planets around nearby M-type stars.
